issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

fields.description:

fields.summary: broken links in Admin Guide commands

comments.body:
[~tvo] I believe these 2 DITA files are just not yet checked in?

In general, I want to know why we are putting Euca admin commands in the euca2ools directory. Do you know? Is that what is really happening? Should it be that way? 

I am creating 2 new commands (nodeadmin-pack-instance and nodeadmin-unpack-instance) and so should learn how this works (or should work), so I put the 2 new DITA files in the correct place. Was planning to add them to the admin guide on this page, unless somebody tells me it should be different. thanks!

cc: [~gholms]
Oh I think this is a casualty of DOC-1871. Still wonder about my questions though - as to where we put the commands in our doc content directories.

Just be careful with how you phrase and organize them.  We ship three types of commands:

# euca2ools - (mostly) AWS-compatible web service client tools
# eucalyptus admin tools - Eucalyptus-specific web service client tools for cloud administrators
# service support scripts - Service-specific tools installed with and only functional alongside those services

Be careful not to conflate the latter two.  The former two can run from anywhere.  To run service support scripts one must be logged into the relevant machines.
